awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL ABSTRACT
This individual investigator award supports a project directed towards experimental studies of fundamental optical and electronic properties of structures made of thin layers of semiconductors. A special design of the structures on a length scale of a billionth part of a meter allows the creation of new quasi-particles called indirect excitons. The indirect excitons are unique because they can be cooled down to ultralow temperatures. Furthermore, the indirect excitons are unique because they can be electronically controlled like electrons in electronic devices and can emit optical signals. The project is directed towards increasing our understanding of the physics of ultracold indirect excitons. The understanding gained through this research may lead to the exciting possibility of developing advanced devices that make use of electronic as well as optical properties, i.e. optoelectronic devices. Undergraduate and graduate students will be involved in this project and will have the opportunity to perform research on the cutting edge of contemporary physics. The training they receive will prepare them for employment in high-tech industries across the nation.

TECHNICAL ABSTRACT
This individual investigator award supports a project directed towards experimental studies of cold indirect excitons and cold electron-hole plasma in coupled quantum well semiconductor structures. Indirect excitons are formed by electrons and holes confined in spatially separated quantum well layers. Due to their long lifetime, indirect excitons can cool below the temperature of quantum degeneracy. This gives an opportunity to study cold excitons. Due to their long lifetime, indirect excitons can travel over large distances before recombination. This gives an opportunity to study exciton transport. Furthermore, indirect excitons are dipoles and their energy can be controlled by voltage. This gives an opportunity to create a variety of potential landscapes for indirect excitons and use them as a tool for studying cold excitons – cold composite bosons in materials. Studies include transport of cold indirect excitons in basic mesoscopic devices – quantum point contacts, and cold electron hole plasma in separated electron and hole layers. The research is performed by students and is integrated with education. The potential impact of the project is in development of knowledge in condensed matter physics and increase of fundamental understanding of optical and electronic properties of materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
An exciton is a bound pair of an electron and a hole. Excitons mediate the absorption and emission of light in semiconductors and transfer energy in materials. We study specially designed excitons - the indirect excitons (IXs). An IX is composed of an electron and a hole confined in separated layers. Due to the separation between the electron and hole layers, IXs have the unique properties: IXs have long lifetimes, can travel over large distances, can be effectively controlled by voltage, and can cool down and form a quantum system.

Within this NSF project on IXs, we studied IXs in GaAs heterostructures (HS) and in van der Waals transition metal dichalcogenide (TMD) HS. GaAs HS give the opportunity to explore basic properties of IXs in a low-disorder platform. IXs in TMD HS are characterized by remarkably large binding energies and give the opportunity to explore excitonic quantum gases and to create excitonic devices at high temperatures.

The outcomes of the NSF project include the following.

- We developed fabrication of the highest quality TMD HS for IXs with the narrow IX luminescence linewidth [Nano Letters 20, 1869 (2020)] and the long-range IX transport [arxiv2204.09760 (2022)].

We found new fundamental phenomena, including the following:

- We found dislocations in interference patterns produced by condensate of IXs, found that these dislocations originate from a new mechanism - the moire effect in interference patterns, and found that these dislocations are formed by IXs ballistically propagating over long times that evidences for IX superfluidity [Nature Commun. 12, 1175 (2021)].

- We explored IXs in GaAs HS with two IX layers and found monotonic IX energy reduction in one layer with increasing IX density in the other layer and the attraction between IX clouds in different layers, showing the attractive dipolar interaction in the bi-layer IX system [Physical Review B 103, 045126 (2021)].

- We realized control of IX transport in TMD HS by voltage and found that this control is governed by the new mechanism, which was attributed to the control of moire superlattice potentials by voltage [Physical Review B 104, 165302 (2021)].

- We realized ultra-cold neutral dense electron-hole systems, found a strong enhancement of luminescence intensity at the Fermi energy - the Fermi edge singularity due to the Cooper-pair-like IXs at the Fermi energy, and observed a crossover from the hydrogen-like IXs in dilute system to the Cooper-pair-like IXs in dense ultracold electron-hole system [arXiv:2209.06026 (2022)].

- We found IX long-range transport with the decay distances reaching and exceeding 100 microns, more than 30x longer than achieved earlier in TMD HS [arxiv2204.09760 (2022)].

The performed research increases our knowledge of the basic properties of light and matter. The studies of exciton transport, interaction, coherence and condensation, and the studies of dense ultracold electron-hole plasma contributes to the basic physics of quantum systems.

The developed instrumentation for imaging spectroscopy at ultralow temperatures allows accessing the previously unavailable range of temperatures for imaging spectroscopy. The developed methods to control excitons have applications both in studying the basic physics of ultracold bosons in materials and in the development of optoelectronic devices.

The performed research had a strong educational component. Five graduate students of the PI group have been involved in the research of the NSF project. The results were broadly disseminated in scientific meetings, conferences, and schools. Educational webpage on indirect excitons was supported. Lectures and experiment demonstrations were given for elementary and middle school students in the University of California San Diego Young Physicists Program. Highlights on the results obtained within the NSF project were done in Physical Review B Editor's Suggestion, UCSD News, and MRS Webinar on Emergent Quantum materials.
